body.p: In the Asia-Pacific region, health care and public health is a major area of budgetary expenditure. This journal has always advocated for a balance between public health, with its emphasis on prevention and population-wide health programs, and expenditure on health care. Health care services emphasize treating the individual and for this reason tend to be biased toward higher income citizens who live in the cities. Public health emphasizes “health for all,” no matter how poor or disadvantaged the citizen may be. To achieve health for all, there needs to be an appropriate balance between curative medicine and preventive health care.

But a new epidemic threatens the balance between public health and clinical medicine in our region. This issue of the journal again includes articles on obesity from Thailand and Japan and articles on exercise. The public health answer to obesity is simple and well known—and yet so complicated to adopt on a community-wide basis: “breastfeed all infants,” and for children and adults, “eat less and move more.” Yet because the public health community has not been able to implement this strategy universally, we are faced with an increasing epidemic of obesity. While there are issues with accuracy in diagnosis due to varying definitions, the trend toward an increasingly obese population in the Asia-Pacific region is incontrovertible.1 Walpole et al2 have estimated that the prevalence of overweight in Asia had reached 24% in 2005, and studies since then have reported that rates are still increasing. In China, the news media coverage of obesity has increased in recent years, reflecting the epidemiological reality. But the problem is still portrayed in the popular press as a problem belonging to the individual placing little emphasis on community-wide prevention.3

The relationship between obesity and chronic disease has been documented in many epidemiological studies. Increased morbidity and mortality that is associated with obesity includes diabetes, coronary heart disease, and stroke, to name but a few of the conditions that are commonly listed in reviews.4 In a major cohort study, Chen et al5 documented the excess mortality in China due to obesity. For each 5 kg/m2 increase in body mass index, the mortality from stroke and coronary heart disease increased by 50%.

There have been many attempts to apply an economic cost to the obesity epidemic. Wang and colleagues have projected that in the United States, the total health care costs attributable to obesity and overweight will double every decade to reach 860 to 960 billion US dollars by 2030.6 Obesity will conservatively account for 16% to 18% of total US health care costs, a massive imposition on even the wealthiest economy in the world. In another study, the additional cost of health care of being obese was estimated at $2741 (in 2005 dollars).7 In New Zealand, the cost of obesity added 4.4% to the health budget.8 In Australia, in 2005, the annual cost of health care per person was $1472 for those of normal weight, but this almost doubled to $2788 for those who were obese.9 Obesity increases the cost of treatment of illness episodes in children, although the exact amount is difficult to quantify.10 Other countries in our region are experiencing similar pressures on treatment facilities and costs from the obesity epidemic.

At the individual level, obesity complicates both the diagnosis and outcome of surgery, and body mass index is an independent risk factor for poor outcomes of surgery to the extent that some authors are suggesting that obese patients should be required to lose weight before surgery.11 Not only does obesity predispose to the development of osteoarthritis of the knee, it also prejudices the outcome after surgery.11 A meta-analysis of laparoscopic colorectal surgery showed an increased complication rate in obese patients.12 For example, in one of the more common emergency room scenarios, the diagnosis and treatment of acute appendicitis, the diagnosis is made more difficult by obesity and confirmation may involve high-technology scanning such as computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging, adding to the costs of treatment.13 This is shown by the higher incidence of perforation in obese patients and the increased likelihood of operative and postoperative complications.14,15

Obesity is resulting in an increase in the number of cases that require treatment, for conditions as diverse as arthritis, various cancers, and heart disease. But additionally, obesity increases the complexity and the costs of treating each case. It is difficult to ration care when faced with an acute medical problem, and so the increasing morbidity associated with obesity will promote competition for health expenditure between curative medicine and public health. The total health budget is finite. The tension between curative medicine and public health arises as the costs of treating each individual case increases. Individuals, families, politicians, and the media demand that the immediate needs of the obese patient be met. Where do the resources come from? The temptation is to take the additional hospital funds required from primary health care and public health services. An important role of this journal is to promote debate on the changing epidemiology of the public health burden in the Asia-Pacific region and how this influences the distribution of health resources. In this issue of the journal, we have several articles on the obesity epidemic. What the editors would like to see would be articles that present the results of programs and community interventions that have successfully halted or reversed the epidemic. We would also welcome studies and comments on how to maintain a balance between public health and curative health services in the face of the obesity epidemic.
